metadata.case_name: Writ Petition No. 205 of 1971 (Petitioner v. State of West Bengal)

facts.text: District Magistrate, 24 Parganas passed detention order dated March 2, 1971 under S.3(1) r/w S.3(3) of West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970, satisfied it necessary to detain petitioner to prevent him from acting prejudicial to security of State or maintenance of public order.
District Magistrate reported detention to State Government on March 3, 1971 under S.3(4) with grounds and particulars.
Petitioner arrested on March 5, 1971 and served with detention order and grounds same day; informed of rights to represent to State Government, Advisory Board under Ss.10,11.
State Government approved detention order on March 11, 1971 under S.3(4) and reported to Central Government under S.3(5).
Petitioner's case placed before Advisory Board on April 3, 1971.

Petitioner made representations dated March 17, 1971 and April 19, 1971 denying allegations in grounds of detention, admitting arrest on March 5, 1971, claiming innocence as mason; no request for personal hearing before Advisory Board.
State Government rejected representations but forwarded to Advisory Board.
Advisory Board considered materials including representations and reported on May 11, 1971 that sufficient cause for detention.
State Government confirmed detention on July 12, 1971 under S.12(1), directing continuance for 12 months from detention date.

Grounds of detention: On 26-1-71 between 11.00-12.31 hrs at Piali Railway Station, petitioner with associates armed with bombs, ballasts, pipe guns, lathis etc., terrorized passengers on trains SC 193 UP and SC 195 UP, injured innocents, broke glass panes, disturbed public order.

Grounds of detention: On 2-2-71 at 17.39 hrs at Champahati Railway Station, petitioner with associates armed with bombs, daggers assaulted guard of train SC 199 UP, terrorized passengers by charging bomb, disturbed public order.

Grounds of detention: On 9-2-71 at 13.15 hrs at Jadavpur Railway Station, petitioner and associates charged bombs and ballasts on police seizing 10 bags rice (3 quintals) from SC 195 UP being smuggled to Calcutta; police fired in self-defence, created panic, disturbed public order.
Petitioner denies committing any offence, involvement in illegal activities or incidents in grounds of detention; claims allegations false, innocent.

Counter-affidavit by District Magistrate: Petitioner rice smuggler on suburban trains, with associates armed, attacked passengers/guards at Champahati/Piali, leading violent activities in Jadavpur disturbing public order, terror to locality/railway public; detention essential based on reliable info.
Counter-affidavit erroneously states Advisory Board heard petitioner in person (corrected by counsel, no impact).

legal_issues.text: Validity of detention order dated March 2, 1971 under West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970.
Whether grounds of detention only relate to disturbance of public order and not security of State, rendering order invalid as extraneous/irrelevant matters considered.
Whether grounds vague or fail to inform petitioner of basis for detention prejudicial to security of State.

petitioner_arguments.text: Never committed offence or involved in illegal activities; allegations in grounds false, never participated in incidents; innocent, illegally detained.
Every ground refers to disturbance of public order only; order mentions security of State or public order but no grounds furnished for security of State; extraneous/irrelevant matters considered.
Unclear if detention to prevent acting prejudicial to security of State or public order; only S.3(2)(a)(i) relates to security of State.

respondent_arguments.text: Activities in grounds fall under acting prejudicial to security of State or maintenance of public order per S.3(2); committed offence under Explosive Substances Act, 1908.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.3(2)(d) of the Act; Explosive Substances Act, 1908

respondent_arguments.text: Detaining authority satisfied based on materials; all procedural requirements followed; no mala fides.

court_reasoning.text: S.3(1) requires satisfaction of necessity to detain to prevent acting prejudicial to security of State or public order; grounds furnished with particulars of dates, places, times, trains; not vague.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Names of associates not given but sufficient particulars provided.

court_reasoning.text: S.3(2) defines 'acting prejudicial to security of State or public order' via cls.(a) to (e); all such acts prejudicial to both; not limited to (a)(i); grounds fit cls.(d) (Explosive Substances Act offence disturbing public order) and possibly (b).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act furnishes dictionary meaning; activities under S.3 Explosive Substances Act, 1908.

court_reasoning.text: Petitioner merely denies association; no mala fides, jurisdiction challenge; DM's counter-affidavit uncontroverted; detention validly passed on bona fide satisfaction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Satisfied from averments that order properly passed.

holdings.text: Grounds of detention not vague; activities fall under S.3(2)(d) etc., prejudicial to security of State or public order.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition challenging detention.

statutes_cited.name: West Bengal Prevention of Violent Activities Act, 1970 (Act No. XIX of 1970)
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers for detention order, approval, Advisory Board, confirmation; definition of prejudicial acts.

statutes_cited.name: Explosive Substances Act, 1908 (Act No. 6 of 1908)
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of causing explosion likely to endanger life/property; grounds invoke cl.(d) S.3(2) of 1970 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Mischief by fire/explosive in S.3(2)(b) of 1970 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Bad livelihood cases in S.3(2)(e) of 1970 Act.

outcome.summary: Court upheld validity of detention order dated March 2, 1971, all procedural steps followed, grounds sufficient and fitting statutory definition; petition challenging detention dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "the District Magistrate was satisfied that with a view to prevent the petitioner from acting in any manner prejudicial to the security of the State or the maintenance of public order, it is necessary to detain the petitioner"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We are satisfied from the averments made by the District Magistrate in the counter-affidavit, which have not been further controverted by the petitioner by filing any rejoinder that the order of detention has been validly and properly passed."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "For all the above reasons, we are satisfied that the order of detention is valid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
